[1]
Lutfy, J.
: The applicant is an Iranian national who maintains that he has converted from Islam to Zoroastrianism, an offence punishable by death in Iran. On arrival in Canada, he claimed Convention refugee status due to persecution on religious grounds. The Convention Refugee Determination Division did not believe that the applicant had become a Zoroastrian and denied his claim. The applicant challenges this determination. The second of two tapes used to record the tribunal hearing has been misplaced. One of the principal issues raised by the applicant is whether the rules of natural justice require a new hearing in the absence of a complete transcript.

[2]
It is common ground, and indeed now trite law, that the Convention Refugee Determination Division has complete jurisdiction to determine the plausibility of testimony. [see footnote 1] Where the reasons for its decision on credibility must be stated in clear and unmistakable terms, [see footnote 2] this court will only interfere in exceptional circumstances.

[3]
Counsel for the parties canvassed the relevant case law concerning the consequences of an incomplete record, where there is no statutory requirement for a hearing transcript.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  transcript, due to the malfunctioning of a recording machine during a refugee hearing, did not constitute a failure to observe a principle of natural justice. In noting that the C.R.D.D. decision may be subject to judicial review, Justice Pratte added:
"However, a meaningful right of review may exist without a transcript or a recording of the proceedings. In the absence of a transcript, the appellant may establish by other means what transpired at the hearing. This is specially true of the hearings before the Refugee Division where the applicant is always present and, in most cases, is the only witness heard." [see footnote 4]
In <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , the panel chose not to follow a contrary decision of the Court of Appeal in
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  the court. In
Tung
, Justice Stone wrote that "... the failure to have available a full verbatim transcript of the proceedings has prejudiced the appellant in prosecuting this appeal and has thereby denied him natural justice".

[4]
This conflicting case law was recently reviewed by the Supreme Court of Canada in
Syndicat canadien de la fonction publique, section locale 301 v. Montréal (Ville)
. [see footnote 6] In concluding that the decision in <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> was more consistent with the traditional approach, Justice L'Heureux-Dubé summarized her understanding of that case and stated the guiding principle where the record of the administrative tribunal's hearing is incomplete:
"In <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , the Federal Court of Appeal acknowledged the concern underlying the decision in
Tung
, that is, that an applicant may be deprived of his or her grounds of review or appeal given an absence of a transcript of what transpired at the impugned hearing. It held, however, that if the decision facing the court could be made on the basis of evidence established through other means, the principles of natural justice would not be infringed.
. . . . .
"In the absence of a statutory right to a recording, courts must determine whether the record before it allows it to properly dispose of the application for appeal or review. If so, the absence of a transcript will not violate the rules of natural justice. Where the statute does mandate a recording, however, natural justice may require a transcript.
. . . . .
"... in the absence of a statutory right to a recorded hearing, a party's rights to natural justice will only be infringed where the court has an inadequate record upon which to base its decision." [see footnote 7]

[5]
In this case, the tribunal based its negative finding of credibility concerning the applicant's claim that he had converted from Islam to the Zoroastrian faith on several grounds. First, the tribunal expressed disbelief that someone who claimed acts of persecution suffered as a result of his conversion "... would not, once he arrived in Vancouver, make contact with the Zoroastrian community". Yet, the applicant testified that he attended sessions, "a number of times", with a representative or member of Vancouver's Zoroastrian community. [see footnote 8] Similarly, the tribunal's finding that the applicant "did not know the names of the leaders and representatives of the Zoroastrian community in either Iran or in Canada" ignores, in the absence of any other explanation, his evidence identifying an elder of the Zoroastrian community in Teheran. [see footnote 9] He also identified the community representative in Vancouver. It is difficult to understand why the tribunal did not accept this testimony of the applicant where he names representatives, if not leaders, of the Zoroastrian community. The tribunal further erred in stating that the applicant "did not know of the famous Zoroastrian temple in Yazd". In fact, the applicant was asked if he knew the location of "a temple ... Jameh-e-kabir" which, according to the documentary evidence, is an Islam mosque and not a Zoroastrian temple. [see footnote 10]

[6]
Neither the
Immigration Act
[see footnote 11] nor the
Convention Refugee Determination Division Rules
[see footnote 12] requires the recording of the hearing. As appears to be the common practice in refugee hearings, however, this tribunal chose to record its proceeding. The partial transcript alone discloses three apparently unsubstantiated findings by the tribunal. The applicant's failure to provide a more fulsome affidavit concerning his testimony on the missing tape is saved by the important discrepancies in comparing the reasons for decision with that portion of the transcript that is available. These discrepancies may be sufficient reason to set aside the decision, particularly if the complete transcript were available for review. In this case, no meaningful judicial review can be achieved with the partial transcript, one which discloses potentially serious errors. The incomplete record does not allow me, in the words of Justice L'Heureux-Dubé in
CUPE
, [see footnote 13] "to properly dispose of this application for judicial review" on the substantive issues. In view of this conclusion, I need not deal with the applicant's other grounds.

[7]
Accordingly, this application for judicial review will be granted and the matter referred for rehearing before a differently constituted panel. Neither party suggested the certification of a serious question.
Application allowed.
Editor: Jocelyne M. Caissie/kaw

7.Ibid. at paragraphs 76, 81 and 83  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> .
8.Tribunal record, pp. 27 and 36.
9.Tribunal record, p. 26.
10.Tribunal record, pp. 28-9 and 202.
11.R.S.C. 1985, c. I-2.
12.SOR/93-45.

statutes: Convention Refugee Determination Division Rules SOR/93-45
legal_issues: The impact of an incomplete record on the right to a fair hearing in administrative proceedings.
Whether the absence of a complete record violates principles of natural justice when exercising judicial review of an administrative decision.
The standard of review applicable to findings of credibility made by administrative tribunals.
The circumstances under which a rehearing is warranted due to deficiencies in the record of an administrative hearing.
The evidentiary requirements for establishing a claim based on religious persecution.
factual_background: An Iranian national applied for Convention refugee status in Canada, claiming persecution based on a conversion from Islam to Zoroastrianism.
The Convention Refugee Determination Division (CRDD) denied the claim, expressing disbelief regarding the applicant's conversion.
A portion of the audio recording from the CRDD hearing is missing.
The applicant challenges the CRDD's determination, citing concerns about the lack of a complete record of the hearing.
The CRDD based its decision on the applicant's alleged lack of connection to the Zoroastrian community in both Iran and Canada, and a perceived lack of knowledge about a Zoroastrian temple.
The applicant testified to having contacted a representative of the Zoroastrian community in Vancouver and identified Zoroastrian leaders in Iran.
The CRDD questioned the applicant's knowledge of a Zoroastrian temple, but the question referenced an Islamic mosque instead.
Neither the Immigration Act nor the CRDD Rules require hearing recordings, but the tribunal chose to record the proceedings in this instance.

Applicants: The absence of a complete transcript of the hearing violates the principles of natural justice, preventing meaningful judicial review.
The tribunal's negative credibility finding is based on unsubstantiated findings and errors of fact.
The tribunal incorrectly found the applicant did not contact the Zoroastrian community in Vancouver, despite his testimony to the contrary.
The tribunal incorrectly found the applicant did not know Zoroastrian leaders, ignoring his testimony identifying an elder in Teheran and a representative in Vancouver.
The tribunal incorrectly stated the applicant did not know of the Zoroastrian temple in Yazd, as the question referred to an Islamic mosque.
Discrepancies between the reasons for decision and the available portion of the transcript support setting aside the decision.
Respondents: The Convention Refugee Determination Division (CRDD) has complete jurisdiction to determine the plausibility of testimony.
There is no statutory requirement for a hearing transcript in refugee proceedings.
Even without a complete transcript, a meaningful right of review can exist if the decision can be made on the basis of other evidence.
The absence of a transcript does not violate natural justice if the court has an adequate record to base its decision upon.

court_analysis: The central issue was whether the absence of a complete transcript of the refugee hearing violated the applicant’s right to natural justice. The court determined that, absent a statutory right to a recording, a failure to provide a complete transcript only infringes natural justice if the court lacks an adequate record to properly review the decision.

The court relied on the Supreme Court of Canada’s decision in *Syndicat canadien de la fonction publique, section locale 301 v. Montréal (Ville)*, which established that if the court can make a decision based on evidence established through other means, the absence of a transcript is not a breach of natural justice.

The court found that the available partial transcript revealed potentially serious errors in the tribunal’s reasoning regarding the applicant’s credibility. Specifically, the tribunal disbelieved the applicant’s claim of conversion because he didn’t immediately contact the Zoroastrian community in Vancouver, despite testimony he *had* attended sessions with a community representative.

The court also noted errors in the tribunal’s findings regarding the applicant’s knowledge of Zoroastrian leaders and the location of a Zoroastrian temple, pointing out the tribunal incorrectly identified a mosque as a Zoroastrian temple.

Because the partial transcript highlighted these discrepancies and raised doubts about the tribunal’s reasoning, and because a complete transcript could be crucial for a proper review, the court concluded it could not ‘properly dispose of’ the application for judicial review with the incomplete record.

The court determined that neither the *Immigration Act* nor the *Convention Refugee Determination Division Rules* mandated a recording of the hearing, reinforcing the application of the *CUPE* principle – that the adequacy of the record is paramount when a full transcript is unavailable.
final_outcome: Matter referred for rehearing before a differently constituted panel
